headline: Macquarie bullish on Luckin Coffee as China growth drives profits
summary: Investing.com -- Macquarie has initiated coverage of Luckin Coffee with an Outperform rating, saying the chain is set to benefit from rapid growth in China’s coffee market and its own ability to keep drawing customers with new products.

headline: Fiserv buys CardFree for hospitality expansion
summary: The company said it acquired the California startup that focuses on restaurant and hotel payment systems to expand its Clover point-of-sale business.

headline: Starbucks China valued at about $5 billion by bidders, sources say
summary: STORY: Most of the bidders seeking to buy a portion of Starbucks'  China operations have reportedly submitted offers valuing the business at as much as $5 billion.That would make a potential deal one of the most valuable China unit divestments by a global consumer company in recent years.The update came from two sources close to the matter.The offers would let Starbucks push ahead with the sale in a market where it faces sluggish economic growth and strong competition from local brands.Reuters reported last month that Starbucks invited around 10 potential buyers to submit non-binding bids by early September.The multiple bidders offered for Starbucks China is similar to one of its main rivals Luckin Coffee...A company currently valued at nine times its projected core earnings for the next 12 months.Luckin has been gaining market share against Starbucks by offering lower-priced products and increasing its presence in smaller Chinese cities.In response to Reuters request for comment, a spokesperson for Starbucks referred to the chain's latest quarterly earnings which saw record-breaking sales growth in international business.The spokesperson declined to comment on the valuation of the China business or the latest status of the bidding process.

raw.headline: Starbucks China valued at about $5 billion by bidders, sources say
raw.summary: STORY: Most of the bidders seeking to buy a portion of Starbucks'  China operations have reportedly submitted offers valuing the business at as much as $5 billion.That would make a potential deal one of the most valuable China unit divestments by a global consumer company in recent years.The update came from two sources close to the matter.The offers would let Starbucks push ahead with the sale in a market where it faces sluggish economic growth and strong competition from local brands.Reuters reported last month that Starbucks invited around 10 potential buyers to submit non-binding bids by early September.The multiple bidders offered for Starbucks China is similar to one of its main rivals Luckin Coffee...A company currently valued at nine times its projected core earnings for the next 12 months.Luckin has been gaining market share against Starbucks by offering lower-priced products and increasing its presence in smaller Chinese cities.In response to Reuters request for comment, a spokesperson for Starbucks referred to the chain's latest quarterly earnings which saw record-breaking sales growth in international business.The spokesperson declined to comment on the valuation of the China business or the latest status of the bidding process.

headline: The Week in Numbers: falling tariffs, soaring Eagle
summary: STORY: From how Japan got lower tariffs at last, to how a controversial ad sent American Eagle soaring, this is the Week in Numbers.:: 15%15% is, finally, the U.S. tariff on Japanese cars, down from 27.5%.The lower rate will kick in after Donald Trump signed an order implementing it.That makes good on an agreement struck in July, and drew a big sigh of relief from Japan’s chief trade negotiator.:: $5 billionUp to $5 billion is the value Reuters sources say bidders have put on Starbucks’ operations in China.If a sale goes ahead at that price, it could mark one of the most valuable China unit divestments by a global firm.Starbucks has said it doesn’t plan a full sale of the business, and there’s no word on what size of stake it might offload.:: 33%33% was the surge in shares for American Eagle on Thursday.The retailer has won attention with a marketing campaign featuring actor Sydney Sweeney.Those ads have faced a backlash over perceived racial undertones, but American Eagle says they have driven “unprecedented new customer acquisition” - and will not be stopping.:: 16%Up to 16% is how much Reuters sources say BYD is slashing its sales forecast for the year.If confirmed, that would add to signs that the Chinese EV giant’s era of white hot growth is cooling off.It’s already slowed production at some plants amid weaker consumer demand at home.:: $3,578And just over $3,578 per ounce was the record high hit by gold on Wednesday.The precious metal has been on the up amid bets on a U.S. rate cut and general global jitters, including over the Russia-Ukraine conflict.Investors traditionally see bullion as a safe haven, meaning it tends to gain in times of trouble.

raw.headline: The Week in Numbers: falling tariffs, soaring Eagle
raw.summary: STORY: From how Japan got lower tariffs at last, to how a controversial ad sent American Eagle soaring, this is the Week in Numbers.:: 15%15% is, finally, the U.S. tariff on Japanese cars, down from 27.5%.The lower rate will kick in after Donald Trump signed an order implementing it.That makes good on an agreement struck in July, and drew a big sigh of relief from Japan’s chief trade negotiator.:: $5 billionUp to $5 billion is the value Reuters sources say bidders have put on Starbucks’ operations in China.If a sale goes ahead at that price, it could mark one of the most valuable China unit divestments by a global firm.Starbucks has said it doesn’t plan a full sale of the business, and there’s no word on what size of stake it might offload.:: 33%33% was the surge in shares for American Eagle on Thursday.The retailer has won attention with a marketing campaign featuring actor Sydney Sweeney.Those ads have faced a backlash over perceived racial undertones, but American Eagle says they have driven “unprecedented new customer acquisition” - and will not be stopping.:: 16%Up to 16% is how much Reuters sources say BYD is slashing its sales forecast for the year.If confirmed, that would add to signs that the Chinese EV giant’s era of white hot growth is cooling off.It’s already slowed production at some plants amid weaker consumer demand at home.:: $3,578And just over $3,578 per ounce was the record high hit by gold on Wednesday.The precious metal has been on the up amid bets on a U.S. rate cut and general global jitters, including over the Russia-Ukraine conflict.Investors traditionally see bullion as a safe haven, meaning it tends to gain in times of trouble.

headline: Exclusive-Starbucks China valued at about $5 billion by bidders, sources say
summary: HONG KONG (Reuters) -Most of the bidders seeking to buy a portion of Starbucks' China operations have submitted offers valuing the business at as much as $5 billion, said two people who have knowledge of the deal discussions.  That quotation would make a potential deal one of the most valuable China unit divestments by a global consumer company in recent years.  The offers, which have not been reported previously, would let Starbucks push ahead with the sale in a market where it faces sluggish economic growth and stiff competition from local brands.

That quotation would make a potential deal one of the most valuable China unit divestments by a global consumer company in recent years.  The offers, which have not been reported previously, would let Starbucks push ahead with the sale in a market where it faces sluggish economic growth and stiff competition from local brands.
